Recommendations to Reduce Skin Cancer Risk
Protect Your Skin From UV Rays:

• Stay in the shade during peak UV hours (10 a.m. to 4 p.m.).
 • Wear protective clothing like long sleeves, pants, and wide-brimmed hats.
 • Use sunglasses with UVA and UVB protection to shield your eyes.
 • Apply sunscreen: Use a broad-spectrum SPF 30+ sunscreen (preferably SPF 50) and reapply every 2 hours.
Understand the UV Index:
Check the daily UV Index for your area.
If it’s 3 or higher, take extra precautions to protect your skin.
Avoid Artificial UV Exposure:

• Skip tanning beds, booths, and sunlamps. These devices emit high levels of UV rays, increasing the risk of skin cancer.\n • A tan is a sign of skin damage, not health. Even a “base tan” can harm your skin.
General Sun Safety Tips:

• Stay hydrated: Drink plenty of water when outdoors.\n • Use shade creatively: Umbrellas, trees, and shelters can help reduce UV exposure.\n • Teach children sun safety: Start early with sunscreen and protective clothing to instill good habits.
End-of-Day Skin Care:

• Apply a gentle moisturizer: Rehydrate your skin after cleansing to help restore its natural barrier and lock in moisture. Look for moisturizers with soothing ingredients like aloe vera, hyaluronic acid, or ceramides.
 • Avoid harsh chemicals: Choose alcohol-free and fragrance-free products to prevent irritation.
 • Focus on damaged areas: If your skin feels dry, red, or irritated from sun exposure, use a calming lotion designed for after-sun care.
 • Hydrate internally: Drink plenty of water throughout the day to keep your skin hydrated from within.
Signs of Skin Damage:
Any redness, tanning, or burning is a sign of skin injury. Even slight tanning can lead to long-term damage. Watch for new or unusual moles and consult a dermatologist if you notice changes.
